Hebei Provincial Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Technology & High Efficient Energy Saving Hebei University of Technology Tianjin PR China Hierarchically porous MgO catalysts with high surface area and adjustable alkalinity were prepared with a carbon deposit template in-situ generated via pyrolysis of organic compounds (OCs) in an inert atmosphere. The effects of the preparation parameters, such as calcination temperature, atmosphere, types and dosage of OCs, etc., on the physicochemical properties of synthesized MgO were investigated. The characterization results suggested that the base strength varied with preparation conditions due to the different microstructure caused by various parameters and the influence mechanism of microstructure on the base strength of synthesized MgO was speculated and discussed. A yield of ethyl methyl carbonate as high as 49.5% was achieved for the best sample synthesized in this work at 103 °C in only 20 min. High specific surface area (∼206 m2·g−1), large pore volume (0.48 cm3·g −1) and suitable base strength enable the obtained MgO an eligible candidate for transesterification reaction. Additionally, the new strategy for controlling the base strength of as-prepared MgO also suggested good prospects in other practical applications. Graphical abstract The hierarchically porous MgO catalyst with high surface area and controlling base strength distribution was prepared by using in situ deposited carbon as the template for efficient transesterification synthesis of ethyl methyl carbonate. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Adjustable alkalinity Porous MgO Ethyl methyl carbonate Transesterification High surface area Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As the simplest asymmetric carbonate, ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC) is widely used in nonaqueous electrolytes due to its low viscosity, high dielectric constant and good solubility of lithium [1,2]. Therefore, with the rapid development of lithium-ion batteries, the demand for EMC surged dramatically. The transesterification of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) with ethanol is a common approach to synthesizing EMC, but the formation of three binary azeotropes resulted in the difficult separation of EMC and high energy consumption [3,4]. The synthesis of EMC by oxidative carbonylation requires high temperature and high pressure, which is dangerous and uneconomic [5]. Compared with the above methods, the transesterification of DMC with diethyl carbonate (DEC) is an ideal method for producing EMC due to some advantages, such as eco-friendliness, atom economy and mild reaction conditions [6,7]. Furthermore, no separation is required for this method because all compositions of reaction mixtures including EMC, DMC and DEC can be used directly as cosolvent of electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries [8–10]. Among the reported solid acid/base oxide catalysts, such as MgO, La2O3, ZnO and CeO2, the basic oxide of MgO has attracted great interest due to its relatively high activity [7]. However, the low surface area and unsuitable base strength distribution of MgO catalysts prepared by traditional methods seriously inhibit the further improvement of catalytic performance and limit its application. To enlarge the surface area, some nanosized MgO [11] and a series of MgO-supported catalysts such as MgO/NC-2 [12], and MgO/ZSM-5 [13,14] have been prepared and achieved a higher activity. However, the stability of these catalysts is usually quite poor, for instance, nanosized MgO can be dissolved slowly in the reaction liquid while the active species of supported catalysts would leach slowly due to the weak interaction between active species and supporter [12,14]. Although some works had fabricated porous MgO materials with different morphologies such as rod-like [15], nanoparticles [16,17], hollow microsphere [18] and porous film [19], etc., only a few displayed a high surface area [17]. In recent years, porous hierarchically structure MgO as well as its composites have been developed for CO2 capture and conversion [20,21] and the treatment of wastewater [22], in which the hierarchically porous MgO exhibited excellent performance. The hierarchically porous structure can provide a high surface area, plenty of active sites for adsorption and conversion of CO2, and hierarchical channels for mass transfer. It is well known that different applications require the basic sites with different strengths, whereas, the study on MgO materials with adjustable alkalinity is rarely reported. Therefore, it is still important and challenging to prepare highly efficient and stable heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of EMC via transesterification under mild reaction conditions. It is well known that the catalytic activities correlate well with the strength of the basic sites and/or the number of basic sites, which depends on the textural structure and physicochemical properties of solid base catalysts [23]. Therefore, suitable alkalinity is beneficial to improve the catalytic performance of base catalysts for a certain reaction. According to the results of previous work [24], there are three types of Mg-O ion pairs with different coordination numbers existing on the surface of MgO and the base strength varies with the coordination numbers depending on its location, for instance, the ion pairs located at the corner and edges are 3-fold and 4-fold coordination numbers, respectively. Hence, fabricating hierarchically porous structures in MgO materials not only can achieve a high surface area but also can adjust the base strength by changing the microstructure of MgO, which is a meaningful thing for preparing an efficient solid basic catalyst. Herein, the template of carbon deposit in situ formed via pyrolysis of OCs was adopted to synthesize hierarchically porous MgO materials with a large specific surface area and adjustable base strength, in which PEG20000 (PEG) and/or D-glucose (DG) were used as carbon sources. The effect of synthesis parameters, such as calcination temperature, calcination atmosphere and type and dosage of OCs on the physicochemical properties of obtained MgO materials was investigated. Moreover, their catalytic performance was evaluated through catalytic the liquid-phase transesterification reaction of DMC with DEC. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation A typical procedure for preparing porous MgO catalysts is as follows: Firstly, a certain amount of OCs was added into 47.6 g of magnesium acetate tetrahydrate (MAT, Mg(CH3COO)2·4H2O) solution (30 wt%) under vigorous stirring at ambient temperature. After stirring for 0.5 h, the solid precursor was obtained by removing most of the water from the mixture solution by rotary evaporation under vacuum at 50 °C and then was thoroughly dried at 110 °C for 6 h. Finally, the solid powder was calcined at 500 °C with a heat rate of 1 °C/min and kept for 3 h in nitrogen flow and then slowly changed to oxygen flow for another 2 h at the same temperature, and the final material was obtained after cooling to room temperature. The obtained materials were denoted as M-mG-nP-T, where M represents MgO, G and P stand for the OCs of DG and PEG, m and n are the mass percentages of G and P relative to MAT, respectively, and T is the calcination temperature. 2.2 Characterizations The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Bruker D8 Discover X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation and a Ni filter at a scanning rate of 8°min−1 in the 2θ range of 30–80° (λ = 0.15405 nm, 40 kV, 40 mA, step size = 0.02 o). Thermal analysis (TGA) was conducted on an HCT-3 thermal analyzer in an N2 atmosphere from 50 °C to 750 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) micrographs were observed on an FEI Nova Nano SEM450 machine operated at 25.0 KV. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded at −196.15 °C on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer. Pore size distributions were calculated by adsorption branches of nitrogen isotherms. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was measured on a NICOLET NEXUS-470 with a resolution of 1 cm−1 by using KBr wafers (1 wt% catalyst mixed with 99 wt% KBr). The temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) was carried out on Autochem II 2920 with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The detailed process is as follows: 100 mg of sample was first preheated at 500 °C under flowing He for 0.5 h to remove physisorbed species, then cooled to 50 °C. Subsequently, the sample was exposed to flowing CO2 for 0.5 h and then purged by He gas for 1 h to remove excessive physisorbed CO2, after which the sample was heated to collect the desorpted CO2. 2.3 Catalytic reactions To evaluate the catalytic performances of synthesized MgO for transesterification reaction, a typical procedure was conducted as follows: 9.0 g (0.1 mol) of DMC, 11.8 g (0.1 mol) of DEC and 1.0 g of the catalyst were added into a 50 mL flask equipped with a ball condenser. Then the mixture was refluxed under stirring for a certain time at normal pressure. The reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC-7890B) equipped with an HP-5 capillary column (30 m × 320 μm × 0.25 μm) and FID detector. To investigate the stability, the synthesized MgO catalysts were recovered by centrifugation and washed with ethanol 3 times and reused for the next reaction without any other further processing. Unless otherwise stated, the reaction conditions were as follows: the catalyst dosage was 4.6 wt%, the reaction temperature was 103 °C, raw materials n(DMC)/n(DEC) = 1:1, and the reaction time was 20 min. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalysts characterization Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of MgO prepared with different conditions. It can be observed from Fig. 1a that no diffraction peaks attributed to impurities were indexed, indicating the obtained materials are pure MgO (JCPDS No. 45–946). It can also be seen that the diffraction peaks become stronger and sharper with increasing calcination temperature, which is similar to the previous results [25]. This may be attributed to the fact that the MgO particles generated through pyrolysis of magnesium salt at relatively low temperatures are smaller than those of at high temperatures. Because the initial particles of MgO formed by pyrolysis of magnesium salt would further gather together at high temperatures, resulting in the growth of MgO particles, and displaying strong diffraction peaks [26]. Furthermore, the XRD patterns as shown in Fig. 1b indicated that pure MgO materials were also obtained by using different OCs as carbon sources with the same method. However, the intensity of diffraction peaks for those samples varied with the types and dosages of OCs. This can be attributed to the fact that the properties of OCs and their distributions in precursors display a key role in the fabrication of the porous structure. To determine the initial temperature of calcination, the precursor mixture of MgO materials was analyzed firstly by TG technology. As presented in Fig. 2 , the single MAT precursor did not display a significant weight loss until the temperature reached 320 °C, however, it suffered a sharp weight loss in the temperature range of 320–450 °C, especially in the range of 320–350 °C, and a weight loss about 60% was observed due to the loss of crystallization water and the pyrolysis of MAT to form MgO and carbon deposit. The mixture of MAT and PEG also exhibited a similar weight loss curve, which can be ascribed to the fact that the temperature range for PEG complete pyrolysis is close to that of MAT [27]. However, the mixture of MAT, PEG and DG gave an obvious weight loss curve covering a wide temperature range from 200 °C to 550 °C, which included three stages corresponding to the slow decomposition of DG, the rapid decomposition of the mixture and the further carbonization of DG in micropores [28], respectively. Although no diffraction peaks due to the impurities can be detected from the XRD pattern as given in Fig. 1a, the gray color of the sample calcined at 400 °C indicated that the carbon deposit was not removed thoroughly because of insufficient combustion caused by too low annealing temperature, which can be further proved by its low surface area, small pore size and volume as shown in Table 1 . Therefore, the required annealing temperature should be higher than 400 °C. On the other hand, it also can be concluded from Table 1 that too high calcination temperature would lead to the collapse of pores to form a dense phase, resulting in an evident decrease in S BET [28], whereas, the pore volume did not decrease significantly which may be attributed to the formation of larger pores due to the collapse of small pores, which can be demonstrated by the enlarged pore size. As a comparison, the sample prepared by annealing the precursor directly in air was also presented in Table 1 displaying the lowest surface area, which can be ascribed to the inefficiency of the carbon template due to the combustion of OCs during the calcination process because magnesium acetate tetrahydrate and OCs decomposed simultaneously during this process. On the contrary, when the calcination process is conducted in the inert atmosphere, carbon fibers are formed acting as templates to form pores by depositing MgO species around them, after which the fabricated pores would be emptied via removal of the carbon templates by combustion in an oxygen atmosphere at relatively low temperature. Therefore, the carbon deposit template in situ formed by pyrolysis of OCs should support the pores until the formation of a stable MgO porous structure. The results presented in Tab.S1 suggested the introduction of OCs into the precursor improved the textural properties of obtained MgO materials. Furthermore, it can be easily found that DG is more effective than PEG in enlarging the surface area of synthesized MgO, which can be ascribed to the fact that the pyrolysis temperature range of PEG is close to that of MAT, while that of DG is higher than that of MAT, which had been confirmed by the abovementioned TG results. Therefore, during the calcination process, DG can act as the template for fabricating a large number of pores, but the decomposition of PEG simultaneous to that of MAT makes it inefficient to support the pore structure. Whereas, an excess of OCs would lead to a sharp decline in the surface area of synthesized materials. It can be explained by the fact that the more OCs used, the more carbon deposits formed by their pyrolysis. Therefore, the pore wall of MgO will be too thin or even discontinuous to form a stable framework, resulting in the collapse of the porous structure after removing the carbon deposit template. As shown in Fig. 3 , all the obtained samples have type Ⅳ isotherms, suggesting the existence of mesopores according to the IUPAC classification [29]. The H2-type hysteresis loops appeared in the high relative pressure region (P/Po > 0.4), displaying a continuous increase of N2 adsorption at a higher relative pressure ((P/Po > 0.8), indicating that all the samples are typical mesoporous materials with some macropores [30,31], which can be further confirmed by the SEM images (Fig. 4 ), especially for the materials prepared with a large dosage of OCs. Moreover, even the sample obtained from the system without any extra OCs also possesses abundant pores, which may be ascribed to the formation of deposited carbon via pyrolysis of acetate. The insets of Fig. 3 indicated that the pore size of obtained samples was enlarged by increasing the OCs dosage. By comparing the textural properties of samples M-0G-0P-500 and M-0G-9P-500, which possess similar pore size and surface area (See Tab. S1), it can be concluded that the PEG is not an ideal carbon source for fabricating mesoporous MgO in this work. Nevertheless, the SEM images shown in Fig. 4 revealed that the material particle size was reduced obviously after introducing some PEG into the synthesis system. Furthermore, the surface area, pore size and pore volume were enlarged evidently (See Tab. S1 and Fig. 3) by introducing some DG into the synthesis system. Hence, both DG and PEG were used as carbon sources to prepare porous MgO with a large surface area and a large number of base sites. Fig. 4 exhibits the SEM images of MgO materials prepared with different OCs. It can be observed that the sample synthesized without any OCs consists of irregular spheres and/or hemispheres with different diameters (Fig. 4a), and the macropore gave it a fluffy structure. Whereas different morphologies were observed for samples when some OCs were added into the synthesis system, for instance, the particles of MgO synthesized with PEG or DG are spherical, and the particle size of the sample for the former is smaller than that of the latter (Fig. 4b,c), moreover, the bulk samples with abundant macropores were obtained when simultaneously introduced both PEG and DG into the system. By careful comparison, it can be found that the microstructure of synthesized samples varied with the dosage of OCs (Fig. 4d–f). It seems that sample M-46G-9P-500 (Fig. 4e) possesses more macropores, however, sample M-69G-9P-500 (Fig. 4f) consists of a large number of fine particles giving a relatively low surface area, which is consistent with the BET results. Consequently, based on the results of N2 adsorption-desorption and SEM, it can be concluded that we had successfully prepared pure MgO with a porous structure consisting of different size pores in this work. The results of TPD given in Fig. 5 suggested that all samples synthesized with different calcination temperatures displayed a broad CO2 desorption peak in the range from 50 °C to 400 °C, which can be deconvoluted into three separate peaks centralized around 100 °C, 170 °C and 240 °C (See Tab. S2), respectively, by multi-peaks Gaussian fitting method. According to previous studies [32], the former should correspond to the weak basic sites (B W ) and the latter two belong to sub-medium (B SM ) and medium basic sites (B M ), which are ascribed to the Brönsted basic sites (OH− groups), metal-oxygen pair (Mg-O) and strong Lewis basic sites (O2− anions), respectively. Based on the peak areas of CO2 desorption in the deconvoluted TPD profiles, the number of basic sites with different base strengths was calculated and presented in Tab. S2, from which it can be observed that the total basic sites varied evidently with calcination temperature, and the M-46G-9P-500 exhibited the highest basic site amount, which is attributed to its highest surface area (See Table 1) in a certain extent, but it is not the determinant of the number of basic sites because the surface area of sample M-46G-9P-600 is also similar to that of M-46G-9P-500, its number of basic sites is only a little more than half of the later, which may be related to the change of textural and surface properties resulted by increasing temperature [33]. Moreover, the content and percentage of Bw decreased evidently with increasing calcination temperature, indicating that calcination temperature is also a key factor in generating basic sites. Nevertheless, the percentage of medium basic site increase with the increase of calcination temperature, suggesting the high calcination temperature favors the generation of medium basic sites (Fig. S1). Because the total number of basic sites for M-46G-9P-500 is much higher than that of other samples, 500 °C is received as the optimal calcination temperature. The effect of the type and dosage of OCs used as carbon sources on the number and strength of basic sites were further investigated by CO2-TPD and the results were presented in Table 2 . It can be observed that both factors affect the basicity of synthesized samples significantly. Compared with sample M-0G-0P-500, sample M-0G-23P-500 has a smaller number of basic sites despite its relatively larger surface area (See Tab. S1), however, sample M-23G-9P-500 gives the largest number. It should be highlighted that the basic site number was reduced obviously when some PEG was added into the synthesis system (See M-23G-9P-500 in Table 2) even though the surface area was enlarged evidently. All the results suggested that DG favors the generation of basic sites, while PEG does not. It can be ascribed to the covering of carbon species generated by PEG pyrolysis on basic sites. Because those carbon species were not thoroughly removed via calcination in the O2 atmosphere, which could be confirmed by the light-gray color of the sample prepared using PEG as a carbon source. Because a high temperature is needed to remove the carbon template [34]. Furthermore, it can be found through a careful comparison that although the total numbers of basic sites of both samples M-23G-0P-500 and M-46G-9P-500 are very close, the percent of BSM and BM is relatively larger in the case of M-46G-9P-500. Fig. 6 shows the FT-IR spectra of (a) carbon materials and (b) the corresponding mixtures of MgO and carbon materials prepared by pyrolysis of different OCs and MgO precursors containing different OCs, respectively, at 500 °C for 3 h under a nitrogen flow. The broadband in the region of 1000–1300 cm−1 can be attributed to CO stretch vibrations [35]. The bands centered at 1640 cm−1 and 2359 cm−1 can be assigned to C=O stretching vibrations and O=C=O asymmetrical stretching vibrations of carbon dioxide, respectively [12,35,36]. The OH stretching vibrations and in-plane deformation vibrations appeared in regions 3100–3500 cm−1 and 1300–1450 cm−1, respectively [12,36]. It can be seen that all the carbon materials possess relatively abundant surface oxygen functional groups. Compared with the carbon materials, the corresponding mixture of MgO and carbon displayed a similar spectrum, but some vibration peaks located in region 1000–1750 cm−1 disappeared or shifted as presented in Fig. 6b, indicating the chemical interaction exists between the oxygen-function groups and MgO species. Therefore, the carbon source influenced the topologies of synthesized MgO because the carbon materials derived from different OCs possess different types and numbers of surface groups as shown in Fig. 6a, which in turn affect the surface basicity of synthesized MgO samples as evidenced by the results of CO2-TPD as given in Fig. S2, Fig. S3 and Table 2. 3.2 Catalytic performance The activity evaluation results as shown in Table 3 indicated that the calcination temperature influenced the catalytic activity of synthesized MgO, and a maximum conversion was achieved for the sample calcined at 500 °C, which may be attributed to its large number and suitable strength of basic sites (Tab. S2) [37] due to the largest surface area (Table 1, Fig. 5). As a comparison, the sample obtained by direct calcination in air atmosphere was also used in this reaction, and its relative low conversion may be ascribed to its lower surface area as shown in Table 1, and the decrease of EMC selectivity can be ascribed to the DMC decomposition to generate MeOH. Fig. 7 shows the results of the reaction catalyzed by MgO prepared with different OCs. The introduction of OCs enhanced the catalytic performance due to the enlarged surface area and improved basicity. The M-46G-9P-500 gave the highest EMC yield of 49.5% even in 20 min. Moreover, it should be highlighted that although samples M-46G-9P-500 and M-23G-0P-500 present similar textural properties including surface area, pore size and volume (Tab. S1, Fig. 3) and a similar total number of basic sites (Table 2), sample M-46G-9P-500 displayed a relatively high catalytic activity, which may be attributed to its basic sites with suitable strength as displayed by the CO2 desorption peak in Fig. S3 and Table 2. Hence, it is reasonable to conclude that the medium basic sites play a key role in promoting transesterification, and a similar result was also found by Wang et al. [38]. Fig. 8 gives the reaction results (a) under different temperatures and (b) with different catalyst dosages. It is clear that the reaction rate increased evidently with the increase of reaction temperature and reached the maximum at 103 °C (the azeotropic temperature at normal pressure). It can be explained by the fact that transesterification is an endothermic reaction and a higher reaction temperature is favorable for the formation of EMC [39]. Furthermore, the EMC yield also increased with increasing catalyst dosage and obtained the highest yield of 49.5% with 4.2 wt% catalysts as shown in Fig. 8b. Because all the reaction mixtures (DMC, DEC and EMC) are the main components of solvent in a nonaqueous electrolyte for Li-ion batteries, their ratio should be adjusted according to the actual requirements for application to improve their power performance, which plays crucial roles in improving the transformation of Li+ charge [40]. Therefore, it is meaningful to adjust the composition by controlling the raw material ratio and conversion to realize the direct application of the reaction mixture, which can avoid the separation step of the final reaction mixture. As shown in Table 4 , the composition of the final mixture varies with the ratios of DMC and DEC from 1:2 to 2:1, and it is similar to the previous results [41]. In this way, its molar ratios can be adjusted effectively by only changing the raw material ratio, that is, the final reaction mixture may be used directly without the separation process. The reusability of the synthesized MgO materials plays a key role in their practical application. Therefore, the stability was further evaluated by using sample MgO-46G-9P-500 as a candidate. As exhibited in Fig. 9 , no conspicuous decrease can be observed in 5 recycles, indicating that the prepared MgO catalysts possess excellent reusability in this reaction, and the slight decline in the first few cycles may be caused by leaching of some ultra-fine particles in prepared MgO [42]. The XRD pattern of recycled MgO catalyst (Fig. S5) further proved the good stability of synthesized MgO. 4 Conclusions An efficient catalyst of porous MgO for esterification reaction to synthesize EMC was developed through a new facile scalable synthesis technique, in which the in situ generated carbon deposit was used as a template. The morphologies and pore structure of synthesized MgO strongly depended on the type and dosage of OCs used as carbon sources, which in turn affect the surface basicity. Thus, the strength of alkaline sites can be easily adjusted in a certain extent by simply changing the synthesis process parameters. Under the optimal reaction conditions, a 49.5% EMC yield was obtained through interesterification between DMC and DEC in only 20 min with the catalysis of as-synthesized porous MgO due to the large number and suitable strength of basic sites with a high surface area. Therefore, this work provides a new strategy for adjusting the base strength of MgO materials to realize their high efficiency in different application fields. coredata.dc:description: Hierarchically porous MgO catalysts with high surface area and adjustable alkalinity were prepared with a carbon deposit template in-situ generated via pyrolysis of organic compounds (OCs) in an inert atmosphere. The effects of the preparation parameters, such as calcination temperature, atmosphere, types and dosage of OCs, etc., on the physicochemical properties of synthesized MgO were investigated. The characterization results suggested that the base strength varied with preparation conditions due to the different microstructure caused by various parameters and the influence mechanism of microstructure on the base strength of synthesized MgO was speculated and discussed. A yield of ethyl methyl carbonate as high as 49.5% was achieved for the best sample synthesized in this work at 103 °C in only 20 min. High specific surface area (∼206 m2·g−1), large pore volume (0.48 cm3·g −1) and suitable base strength enable the obtained MgO an eligible candidate for transesterification reaction. Additionally, the new strategy for controlling the base strength of as-prepared MgO also suggested good prospects in other practical applications.
coredata.dc:title: Fabrication of hierarchically porous MgO with high surface area and adjustable alkalinity for efficient transesterification synthesis of ethyl methyl carbonate
